questions.question:
Question 1: What is the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation required to establish the 
diagnosis of infertility in a couple?
questions.explanation:
The accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation to establish the diagnosis of infertility in a 
couple is one year of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse. Infertility is an apparent failure of a couple to conceive while sterility is an absolute inability to 
conceive. Infertility is of two types: • Primary infertility - when there have been no previous pregnancies. • Secondary infertility - when there has been a prior pregnancy (although not necessarily a live 
birth).

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of male infertility?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis. Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is a 
contributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.

questions.question:
Question 3: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of  
.
questions.explanation:
The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted by 
Sertoli cells. GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and 
LH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by the 
Leydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion. 770 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as a part of an infertility workup. The results 
are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia. Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows: • Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen. • Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL. • Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL. • Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology. • Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility. • Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms. Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.

questions.question:
Question 5: While going through a patient's file at an infertility clinic, you note his semen analysis is 
reported to be normal. What had his semen leukocyte level likely been?
questions.explanation:
The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml. The semen sample should be collected after 2-7 days of ejaculatory abstinence. The patient should 
collect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may be 
collected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.

questions.question: Question 6: What does azoospermia refer to?
questions.explanation:
771 
Sold by @itachibot Azoospermia is defined as the complete absence of sperm in semen. Other types of sperm 
disorders are as follows: • Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen. • Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL. • Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL. • Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology. • Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility. • Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.

questions.question:
Question 7: A young couple being treated for infertility require donor semen for artificial insemination. 
Which of the following is the likely cause of infertility here?

options.d: Presence of antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucucs

questions.explanation:
Artificial insemination with donor semen is done in cases of infertility where the husband has 
azoospermia. Azoospermia is defined as a complete absence of sperms. Hence artificial insemination with the 
husband's/partner's semen cannot be performed. Indications for artificial insemination with husband's/partner's semen are: • Chronic medical disorder • Oligospermia after sperm washout • Impotence • Premature and retrograde ejaculation • Hypospadias • Antisperm antibodies in cervical mucus • Unexplained infertility- direct intraperitoneal insemination (DIPI) is done • HIV-positive male or female • X-Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection in cases of genetic and chromosomal abnormalities Indications for artificial insemination with donor semen are: • Azoospermia • Uncorrectable immunological factors • Genetic disease in husband/partner • Chronic ill health Sperms can be frozen and used later for artificial insemination e.g. if the husband requires to 
undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy, or if the husband is a frequent traveler and is not 
available at the time of ovulation. Artificial insemination techniques include: • Intrauterine Insemination (IUI) 772 
Sold by @itachibot • Intrafallopian-tube Insemination • Intracervical Insemination • Direct Intraperitoneal Insemination (DIPI) Steps required to do artificial insemination are: • The semen is washed to remove abnormal sperms, debris, and seminal plasma containing 
antibodies. It is concentrated, and its quality is improved by the 'swim up technique' or by the use 
of the Percoll gradient. • Semen with normal sperms and good motility is obtained. • Around the time of ovulation, semen obtained is inseminated into the female genital tract. About 
0.5 ml of semen is injected 36 hours after hCG injection when the ovarian follicle reaches 20 mm.

questions.question:
Question 8: Indications for artificial insemination with donor's semen are all except 
.
questions.explanation:
Artificial insemination with donor's semen is not indicated in idiopathic male infertility. The 
preferred treatment in such cases is in vitro fertilization (IVF).

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old man with erectile dysfunction requires treatment with sildenafil. Which of the 
following is not a contraindication for the use of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary hypertension is an indication for the use of sildenafil. The contraindications for the use of sildenafil are: • Retinitis pigmentosa • Diabetic retinopathy • Patient on antihypertensive drugs, nitrates • Cardiac disease, previous myocardial infarct, stroke In the treatment of erectile dysfunction, sildenafil in the dose of 25–100 mg is given 1 hour before 
intercourse. However, it does not improve libido.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most common cause of infertility in women?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause for infertility in women is due to ovarian causes. According to WHO, female factor infertility was reported in 37% of infertile couples in developed 
countries. Male factor infertility was reported in 8% of infertile couples while 35% of couples had 
both male and female factor infertility. The major ovarian causes of infertility are: • Anovulation (PCOS) • Decreased ovarian reserve, e.g., premature menopause 773 
Sold by @itachibot In women with ovulatory disorders, clomifene and metformin increase ovulation and pregnancy 
rates. Less common factors responsible for female infertility are: • Endometriosis • Pelvic adhesions • Tubal blockage • Other tubal abnormalities • Hyperprolactinemia

questions.question:
Question 11: A 34-year-old woman presented with secondary infertility following radiation therapy for 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. You plan to test her ovarian reserve. Which of the following is the best 
indicator of this parameter?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, the level of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is the best indicator of 
ovarian reserve. Ovarian reserve is the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. FSH levels are measured in the early 
follicular phase on day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle. A high FSH level indicates that the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are 
present in the ovary. FSH is high in ovarian hypofunction and postmenopausal women. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve. Unlike FSH, its 
levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle. AMH is produced by the granulosa cells in ovarian 
follicles. Note: Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptive pills and 
tobacco smoking.

questions.question:
Question 12: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve? 763 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml. AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. It 
helps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessing 
ovarian reserve. In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cells 
after puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMH 
is used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea. In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterine 
life. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absence 
of AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism. 774 
Sold by @itachibot AMH levels in ng/ 
ml Interpretation 2–6.8 
Normal <1 
Poor ovarian reserve >10 
PCODHyperstimulation synd 
rome

questions.question:
Question 13: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be 
used to induce ovulation?
questions.explanation:
Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed 
with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from 
day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

questions.question:
Question 14: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrial 
biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.explanation:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium. During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative, 
secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below: Proliferative phase • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium. • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled. • The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present. The image below shows proliferative endometrium Secretory phase 775 
Sold by @itachibot • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of 
menstruation. • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity) • Corkscrew-shaped glands The image below shows secretory endometrium Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.question:
Question 15: The microscopic appearance of the cervical mucus of a woman having irregular periods and 
infertility is shown in the image below. In which phase of the menstrual cycle was this sample 
likely taken?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is seen in the 
estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. A specimen of cervical mucus is obtained using a platinum loop or pipette. This is spread on a 
clean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under the low-power microscope, a palm leaf or 
fern type pattern is seen in the follicular phase. The ferning is due to the presence of sodium 
chloride in the mucus secreted under the effect of estrogen. This pattern disappears after ovulation. If it was previously present, its disappearance is 
presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity. Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical 
mucus becomes thick and tenacious and impenetrable to sperms and bacteria. The below image shows the microscopic appearance of dried cervical mucus showing the fern 
appearance. 776 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is false about the Miller-Kurzrok test?

options.a: Penetration of > 3 cm at 30 minutes is considered normal
options.b: Cervical mucus is placed alongside husband's semen on a glass slide
options.c: It is done at the time of ovulation
options.d: Jerky motility of sperm is considered normal

questions.explanation:
In the Miller–Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus is 
considered abnormal. The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility. 
It is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction. It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. 
It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slide 
alongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the 
microscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considered 
normal. Other special tests in semen analysis include: • Sperm penetration test • Semen–cervical mucus contact test • Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test)

questions.question:
Question 17: 765 
Sold by @itachibot A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite 
staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following 
conditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.explanation:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions: • Sperm count • Sperm morphology • Ferning during the estrogenic effect • Ovulation 777 
Sold by @itachibot • The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration • Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the 
ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The 
mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made 
from the posterior fornix serves as a control. On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus 
is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of 
cervical infection. An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.question: Question 18: During your posting in the infertility clinic, you notice the following instrument. Identify it.
questions.explanation:
The instrument in the given image is Rubin's cannula. It is used while performing a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). The cone prevents the retrograde 
spillage of the dye into the vagina, while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity. This 
investigation is performed to study tubal patency in women. Another cannula that can be used to perform HSG is Spackman cannula. It allows for the 
intra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Asherman 
syndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, but 
no agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?

options.d: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.explanation:
This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions of 
the endometrial surfaces are present. Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows: • Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus 
and tubal ostia. • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine 
wall. • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions. Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways: • Secondary amenorrhea • Oligomenorrhoea • Dysmenorrhoea • Habitual abortions • Infertility The causes of Asherman syndrome are: 778 
Sold by @itachibot • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage • Uterine infection • Tubercular endometritis

questions.question:
Question 20: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the following 
investigation. Which of the following is false about the same?

options.a: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
options.b: It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
options.c: It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
options.d: Premedication can be done with atropine

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital 
tuberculosis. Procedure of HSG: • It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 
9th/10th day of the cycle. • 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's 
cannula, or Foley's catheter. • Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. • If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the 
adjacent bowel. It is used for the detection of: • Tubal block - It can be due to: • Strictures - fibrotic block • Inspissated amorphous material • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with 
atropine and analgesia. • Uterine anomalies • Uterine polyps • Uterine synechiae • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology. Contraindications: • Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading 
infection. • Bleeding • Suspected pregnancy • Allergy to the dye • Premenstrual phase: • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged. 779 
Sold by @itachibot • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end. • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient who has been trying to conceive for the past 6 months underwent 
hysterosalpingography (HSG). The findings are given below. What is your interpretation? 767 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Both fallopian tubes are patent with 
a spill into the peritoneal cavity. The following images show the findings of an abnormal hysterosalpingogram: The hysterosalpingogram given below shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spill 
suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx: The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a unicornuate uterus: 780 
Sold by @itachibot The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a bicornuate uterus/septate uterus: There is an overlap in the appearance of the bicornuate uterus and septate/sub-septate uterus on 
HSG. The distinction lies in the shape of the uterine fundus, which is usually not visible on HSG. 
An ultrasound or MRI should be done to differentiate between these conditions if intervention is 
planned. The hysterosalpingogram given below shows filling defects:

questions.question: Question 22: Which the following are not the advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy?

options.b: Trauma is avoided as no trocar is needed
options.d: Good view of the anterior surface of the ovary and genital organs

questions.explanation:
Fertiloscopy helps in obtaining a good view of the posterior surface (and not the anterior surface) 
of the ovary and genital organs. This is an advantage of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy. The other advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy are: 781 
Sold by @itachibot • The Trendelenburg position is not needed. The procedure can be done in a lithotomy position • Trauma can be avoided as no trocar is needed • No CO2: Hydroperitoneum with saline • Peritoneal spill can be seen Fertiloscopy is a new mini-invasive diagnostic technique that allows the visualization of the 
posterior pelvis. In this technique, an optical device is introduced into the pouch of Douglas, 
through the posterior vaginal fornix, under general/local anaesthesia. It can also be used for small interventions, such as adhesiolysis, ovarian drilling, coagulation of 
endometriosis spots and to perform chromosalpingoscopy and salpingoscopy. With fertiloscopy, 
surgical intervention can be avoided and it is a good alternative to diagnostic laparoscopy. The image given below is of a fertiloscope.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, 
there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the next step in management will be hysteroscopy and 
laparoscopy-guided surgery. Tubal contractions, particularly cornual spasms, can give an incorrect impression of proximal 
fallopian tube obstruction (a false-positive result) on hysterosalpingography. Laparoscopy with 
chromotubation is therefore considered to confirm the diagnosis of cornual spasm. Laparoscopy is 
both diagnostic and therapeutic in this condition. Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides an endoscopic view of the endometrial 
cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix, performed in the preovulatory phase. It can 
be diagnostic or therapeutic. It is the gold standard investigation for visualizing the uterine cavity 
and tubal ostia. Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows: • Acute genital tract infection (Eg: genital herpes infection) 782 
Sold by @itachibot • Viable intrauterine pregnancy • During menstruation, the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high. • Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size  12 weeks are relative contraindications. • Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation. • Cardiopulmonary disorder due to increased risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema. • Known cases of cervical cancer Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the evaluation of tubal factors in infertility, commonly done 
in the proliferative phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. Benefits of laparoscopic evaluation: • Tubes: For detection of tubal patency, block (site and side), motility, hydrosalpinx change, 
peritubal adhesions, fimbrial agglutination • Ovaries: PCOS changes, endometriosis, PID, adhesions • Uterus: Anomalies, fibroids • Peritoneal factors: Adhesions, PID, endometriosis, tuberculosis • Therapy at the same sitting (as appropriate) Diagnosticindications of hyst 
eroscopy Therapeuticindications of hys

questions.question:
Question 24: A woman came to the clinic complaining of amenorrhoea and inability to conceive. She had 
undergone hypophysectomy for a tumour a year ago. What would be the best line of 
management for her?
questions.explanation:
The best line of management for the given patient is human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG) 
followed by hCG. 783 
Sold by @itachibot The patients who have undergone hypophysectomy i.e. removal of the pituitary gland, can not 
produce endogenous gonadotropins. Exogenous gonadotropins such as hMG are given to such 
patients. Timed administration of hCG is needed to induce ovulation after the follicle has 
matured. The human menopausal gonadotropin is an extract of urine from postmenopausal women. It 
contains FSH and LH in the required ratio for follicular growth. Clomiphene, letrozole, and GnRH analogs stimulate the release of gonadotropins from the 
pituitary gland. These are not helpful in a patient whose pituitary gland has been removed. 784 
Sold by @itachibot Perimenopause, Menopause and Post-Menopausal Bleeding
